title: KMT and gas laws - carbon dioxide

content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student is doing experiments with <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Originally, a sample of the gas is in a rigid container at <math alttext="299 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>299</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.70 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student increases the temperature of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container to <math alttext="425 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the effect of raising the temperature on the motion of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student is doing experiments with <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Originally, a sample of the gas is in a rigid container at <math alttext="299 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>299</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.70 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student increases the temperature of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container to <math alttext="425 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the effect of raising the temperature on the motion of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

(b) Calculate the pressure of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container at <math alttext="425 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) In terms of kinetic molecular theory, briefly explain why the pressure of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container changes as it is heated to <math alttext="425 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The student measures the actual pressure of the <math alttext="C O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container at <math alttext="425 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and observes that it is less than the pressure predicted by the ideal gas law. Explain this observation.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
